posts.text:
Upstate Salute Free Concert: Military veterans employed by GE, GHS, Michelin and the Greenville Drive are hosting SC Veterans Upstate Salute at Fluor Field at 5 p.m. today. This free event will include a Tracy Lawrence concert, 21-gun salute, fireworks and opportunities for veterans to learn about services that can help. There is no cost to attend, but registration is required at upstatesalute.com.
Spartanburg Veterans Day Parade: The Veteran’s Day Parade will be held in downtown Spartanburg. It starts at 4 pm at Mt. Moriah Baptist Church at 445 S. Church Street and will end at the Spartanburg Memorial Auditorium. It’s sponsored by the Veteran’s of Foreign Affairs office. “VETERANS DAY”… HONORS ALL WHO SERVED… IN THE U-S ARMED FORCES. ITS OFFICIAL OBSERVANCE… IS ON THE -11TH- DAY… OF THE -11TH- MONTH… MARKING THE ANNIVERSARY… OF THE END OF WORLD WAR ONE.
Easley Vet Day: American Legion Post 52 and Robinson Memorial Gardens, 1425 Powdersville Road, Easley, SC 29642 will host their yearly Veterans Day Ceremony November 11, 2016 11:00 am. Marine Reserve (Battle Director) Colonel Dwight Schmidt is our scheduled speaker. He is a veteran of Afghanistan and Iraq. When on duty he flies F-18’s. This year we will recognize veterans of Desert Storm, Afghanistan and Iraq.
Asheville Vet Day: The Charles George VA Medical Center will honor Veterans on Veterans Day, November 11 with a ceremony at the Charles George VA Medical Center. Beginning at 11 a.m., the ceremony will feature keynote speaker Nicholas Warr, a former Marine, Vietnam Veteran and author. Some highlights of the ceremony will include a releasing of doves and a 21 gun salute. Everyone in the community is invited to attend.
GHS Veterans: More than 100 people will gather outside of the main entrance to Greenville Memorial Hospital at 11 a.m. Veterans Day to recognize GHS employees who served and those who sacrificed their lives for the United States. GHS’ annual Veterans Day Ceremony is organized by GHS employees, and veterans groups from across the community also take part. The community is welcome. The event includes speeches, a 21-gun salute, antique military vehicles. GHS will also unveil donations made to the Blue Star Mothers for their holiday collection drive.
Lander university’s Veterans’ Day Ceremony on Friday, Nov. 11, at 2 p.m. District 14 House Representative Mike Pitts will be the featured speaker during Lander University’s Veteran’s Day ceremony on Friday, Nov. 11.
The program, which is free and open to everyone, begins at 2 p.m. in the Josephine B. Abney Cultural Center Auditorium and will be followed by a reception for attendees.
Veterans will also be admitted free to that day’s 4:30 p.m. Volleyball Military Appreciation Game (Lander vs. Augusta) and the 8:30 p.m. Basketball Military Appreciation Game (Lander vs. Brevard in the Bearcat Classic Tournament).
FREEBIES: This veterans day, active military and veterans can get freebies. Some include meals at Texas Roadhouse and Olive Garden and free appetizer or dessert at LongHorn Steakhouse. Denny’s and iHop are also offering free food. There’s a long list here we can link to– http://www.offers.com/blog/post/veterans-day-freebies/ 
Texas Roadhouse invites veterans and active duty members of the United States military across the country to enjoy a FREE lunch on Friday, November 11. For the 6th year, every Texas Roadhouse location across the country will participate in the free lunch event to honor the men and women of our armed forces.
Who: All veterans – including all active, retired or former United States military – can choose one of 10 entrees, including a 6-ounce sirloin and two made-from-scratch sides plus a choice of any Coca-Cola product, sweet tea/ice tea or coffee during lunch. Guests must show proof of service such as military or VA card, or discharge papers.
When: Friday, November 11 – 11:00am – 2:00 pm
IHOP: On Friday November 11th, IHOP is offering a free stack of their famous Red, White, & Blue Pancakes to all veterans and active duty military to show their appreciation this Veterans Day. IHOP’s Red, White, & Blue Pancakes feature 3 of their world famous buttermilk pancakes, topped with glazed strawberries, blueberry compote, and whipped cream. These patriotic pancakes will be available from 7 a.m. – 7 p.m. for any veteran or active duty military. Share a moment with your favorite veteran this holiday with IHOP’s Red, White, & Blue Pancakes!
To thank the nation’s heroes for their courageous service and dedication, ‘ Dennys < http://www.dennys.com/ > is inviting active, inactive and retired military personnel to stop by for a free Build Your Own Grand Slam® on Friday, Nov. 11, from 5 a.m. to noon.
At participating locations nationwide, diners with a valid military ID will receive a complimentary Build Your Own Grand Slam®, which includes four delicious breakfast items such as new fluffy Buttermilk Pancakes, eggs cooked to order, sizzling bacon strips, seasonal fruit or hash browns.
Olive Garden restaurants will offer a free entrée from a special menu to active-duty military and military veterans. The special menu features six of Olive Garden’s most popular items. Entrées are served with unlimited homemade soup or famous house salad and warm, garlic breadsticks.
LongHorn Steakhouse will offer a free appetizer or dessert (no purchase required, no restrictions) to anyone showing proof of military service. In addition, LongHorn Steakhouse will offer 10% off for guests that dine with Veterans on November 11.
Free Day at the lake: Day use fees will be waived at Hartwell and J. Strom Thurmond projects for veterans, active and reserve component service members, and their families on Veterans Day, Nov. 11, as a small token of appreciation for bold sacrifices.
The waiver covers fees for boat launch ramps and swimming beaches. The waiver does not apply to camping and camping-related services, or fees for specialized facilities such as group picnic shelters. Other agencies that manage recreation areas on U.S. Army Corps of Engineers lands are encouraged, but not required, to offer the waiver in the areas that they manage.

posts.text: 1 Lighting Control with Relays I am attempting to replace GE momentary rocker switches controlling my GE RR9 lighting relays with PCB relays controlled via my computer. The problem I have is that the new PCB relays I purchased work and control the GE lighting relays, but they are either NO or NC and cause the GE RR9 relays to hum continuously. The GE relays are momentary and require only a pulse from their original switches to latch in one position or the other. My new relays replacing the switches have continuous power to the GE RR9 relays. I am concerned that this will cause premature failure of the GE relays and the hum is annoying and I am sure the power consumption is much greater this way as well. thread.title: General Electric & Baker Hughes: The Price is Right? - Stocks to Watch - Barrons.com
thread.title_full: General Electric & Baker Hughes: The Price is Right? - Stocks to Watch - Barrons.com

posts.author: Ben Levisohn
posts.title: General Electric & Baker Hughes: The Price is Right? - Stocks to Watch - Barrons.com
posts.text:
By Ben Levisohn There’s been a lot of debate about how much General Electric ( GE ) is actually paying to combine its oil & gas business with Baker Hughes ( BHI ), so Evercore ISI’s James West and team polled investors to find out what “price is right.” The results:
Agence France-Presse/Getty Images The price is right; Market points to a $60-$65/sh New Baker Hughes fair value . According to General Electric estimates, Baker Hughes shareholders were compensated at a 37% premium (~$76/sh) to the implied ~$55 share price of Baker Hughes equity value. This valuation was largely driven by a combined General Electric/Baker Hughes equity value of $51.9B (incorporating a fair 2018 GEOG EBITDA multiple and PV of cost and revenue synergies) and the prescribed 37.5% Baker Hughes shareholder ownership of the “New Co” equity value. The market points to an elevated New Baker Hughes fair value following the deal, with 43% of total responses suggesting a Baker Hughes fair value of $60-$65/sh . There was a relatively even split among survey participants on each side of the $60-$65 band, with 6% of investors suggesting a fair value less than $55/sh, and 10% signaling a greater than $70/sh price. In terms of a Newco EV/EBITDA multiple, 78% of responders believe the new company should command a 9x-11x EBITDA valuation (43% 9x-10x and 35% 10x-11x). A small minority of investors postulated either <9x or >11x EV/EBITDA, which would suggest that combined company performance could lie outside of the blended 2018 multiple range. We believe Baker Hughes fair value is closer to $70 based on 10.5x 2018E EBITDA of $5.5 billion. We attribute the difference between GE’s valuation of $76 per share and BHI’s current share price to investors not giving the combined entity full NPV of $13.7B for synergies. A 10.5x multiple on synergies of $700 million equates to just $7.4 billion, slightly more than half of GE’s NPV.
Shares of Baker Hughes have risen 0.3% to $59.15 at 12:27 p.m. today, while General Electric has climbed 3.5% to $30.67.

thread.title: The Future Looks Bright For General Electric
thread.title_full: The Future Looks Bright For General Electric

posts.title: The Future Looks Bright For General Electric
posts.text:
GE is a company with a long history, with good times and bad. 
GE pays a nice dividend even if it is frozen for now. 
Its a good buy at $27. General Electric (NYSE: GE ) offers products and services range from aircraft engines, power generation, oil and gas production equipment, and household appliances to medical imaging, business and consumer financing and industrial products. It was incorporated in 1892 It has paid a dividend for many years, and has had several long streaks of raising that dividend every year. It ended up cutting its dividend during the financial crisis, because of problems at GE Capital in large part, and a few years ago froze the dividend again. Click to enlarge Years ago (saying exactly how many will make me feel for too old), GE had the slogan "We bring good things to light." As a kid, my dad worked for GE. The first computer I ever say was at a GE facility in Chicago in 1967, where my dad worked. My high school and college years were spent in upstate new York, where GE had a very large presence, so many of my friends, their parents and even some of my relatives worked for GE. Looking at its position today, are there good things to bring to light? Is GE moving in a direction where it can provide its shareholders a growing dividend payment again? Are shares selling at a price where it's a good value and worth buying it before it starts to raise the dividend? Click to enlarge Earnings Report On October 21 st GE released its 3Q earnings report . Its EPS of $0.32 was in line with expectations. However revenue of $29.27 billion, even though it was 4.4% higher than a year ago, fell short of expectations by $370 million. In its press release about earnings, GE highlighted such good news as an 18% YoY increase in backlog, and a 21% increase in continuing operations EPS. GE also touted its 16% YoY increase in sales for the quarter. The press release also shows details of the GE Capital Exit Plan, and that getting out of that business will remove a significant drag on ongoing operations. What does Morningstar say? Morningstar thinks the GE should be able to sustain a 5 year CGR growth rate on revenue of 4%. They also think that several initiatives have a high likelihood of improving margins, so even without the share buybacks that should lead to EPS growth at or above that range. In their report on GE they do show that TTM revenue, operating income, net income and diluted EPS are all better than they were for 2015. Morningstar also thinks that the installed base of products coupled with the product mix being in segments that are seeing increased capital spending gives them an edge over competitors and makes it hard for customers to replace them. They also think that GE is well placed to provide maintenance service to customers and well suited to help customers upgrade. From reading the premium report and the general complexity of integrating new features into complex systems, GE appears to be well positioned to get back to growth in the future. What's a good price? My thinking on what price to pay for GE is that I want to get it at a price that will represent a value once it begins growing its dividend again. So using DDM, I start with the current dividend. Since Morningstar thinks that GE should be able to sustain a revenue growth rate of 4% and will also be able to improve margins, I will use that as a reasonable yet conservative rate for dividend growth. As usual when I use DDM to estimate fair value, I will use 3% as the long term dividend growth rate (so that the dividend payment about keeps up with inflation) and will use twice the average long term inflation rate as my expected rate of return (which is also the discount rate). That gives me a fair value number of $29.16. While I think GE is a good solid company and is a very good long term holding, at this time there is enough uncertainty in when it will resume growing the dividend that I want a 10% discount to fair value, but also keeping in mind that the 52-week low is $27, my price target is $27 Given that the current yield is 3.1% but the average yield over the last 5 years is 3.25%, GE is currently over-valued. Given the risk that it might not have turned to corner yet, and the fact that management has yet to make a commitment on a date when dividend growth will resume, I think a significant discount to fair value is warranted. With the numbers GE is showing, some could argue that an even larger discount is required, but I think $27 is a good place to buy (although I wouldn't object to more of course). Can options help? Click to enlarge With the market price being around $30 and my target price of $27, its likely to be a while before GE hits that price range. So looking at the February 17 th expiration date, the put contract with a strike price of $27 gives a premium of $0.29. It has only a 14% chance of getting you the shares, but with a limit order you should be able to get a reasonable payment to wait. The $28 strike contract would pay a bit more with a low chance of exercise. Click to enlarge The call contracts are all pretty deep ITM, and so likely to lose you the shares with less than a $1 per share profit. That is a way to make money, but it won't get you the shares long term. Conclusion GE has had some tough times in the last few years going back to the financial crisis. They seem to be finally turning the company around. I think it has a good future. At the present time, other than by selling puts, it's still a bit too expensive to buy right. I have owned it in the past and want to own it again, but for now it will stay on my watch list. I think a price of $27 is about right, while I continue to monitor it to see that it stays on track in its turn around plan. Note: I hope you all got something out of this article. I do appreciate the time you took reading it. If you are one of those who follow me here, I appreciate it; if you'd like to include yourself amongst those individuals, please hit the "Follow" button next to my name as well as following other contributors whose work you enjoy. As always, please leave any feedback and questions you may have in the comments below. Disclosure: I/we have no positions in any stocks mentioned, and no plans to initiate any positions within the next 72 hours. I wrote this article myself, and it expresses my own opinions. I am not receiving compensation for it (other than from Seeking Alpha). I have no business relationship with any company whose stock is mentioned in this article. Additional disclosure: GE is on my watch list but unless it drops to my target price I will not be buying it. About this article: Expand Author payment: $35 + $0.01/page view. Authors of PRO articles receive a minimum guaranteed payment of $150-500. Become a contributor »

posts.text:
GE Profile Series with Keurig (PYE22PMKES) 
As appliance manufacturers work to differentiate themselves, one way they’re doing so is by including smarts. That can mean a full touchscreen or a simple app. GE is setting itself apart by including a Keurig K-Cup brewing system in some of its refrigerator models. The coffee maker is an interesting addition that could potentially save counter space in the kitchen – as long as you’re a fan of Keurig coffee. 
The coffee maker works with one of GE’s more popular features, an integrated hot water dispenser. For some, the coffee maker might be a step too far, but immicks aside, the French-door fridge is spacious and does a solid job at keeping food at the proper temperature. Beyond basics with disco-lighting drawers 
The 22.2-cubic-foot, French-door GE refrigerator is spacious at 69 7/8 by 35 ¾ by 31 ¼ inches (height, width, depth) and should easily accommodate large platters. On the left door panel is the water/ice dispenser and a spot where you can slide in the K-Cup brewer to make coffee. The pull-out freezer drawer has two sections that provides room for plenty of cold items – especially since it lacks an ice bin. (You’ll find that on the left fridge door.) The only design quibble we have is that it has an adjustable divider on each section, making it difficult to fit a large sheet ice cream cake. The fridge comes in either stainless steel or slate gray. Bill Roberson/Digital Trends Bill Roberson/Digital Trends Bill Roberson/Digital Trends 
Setting up the fridge is pretty straight forward. The fridge has two water lines to accommodate the hot and cold water, but you only need one water hookup. This means you’ll get filtered water that’s either hot or cold. Inside there are three adjustable shelves and multiple door shelves (some with anti-slip mats). Each shelf has a specific spot, so don’t try to push a shelf into place if it doesn’t fit. In case you need an extra shelf in a pinch, the butter compartment has a drop-down tray. 
The coffee tastes just as you’d expect of Keurig brewers. 
Located at the lower part of the fridge are three drawers: two for produce (select either fruits or vegetables on the drawer), and one full-width temperature-controlled drawer for larger items like serving platters and wine bottles. The bottom drawer has options for meat (32 degrees Fahrenheit or 0 degrees Celsius), deli (36 degrees Fahrenheit or 2.22 degrees Celsius), and beverages (34 degrees Fahrenheit or 1.11 degrees Celsius). Select the type of food you want to store in the drawer and the temperature and lighting (meat is white, beverage is blue, and deli is green) will automatically adjust. When you open the door, the light in the bottom drawer illuminates based on its setting, which is kind of fun. 
It’s fairly straightforward to adjust the overall temperature of the refrigerator using the controls on the front door panel. The panel on this model isn’t as sleek as those of other GE refrigerator models with the Keurig feature. It has a small digital display that streams messages about the fridge in a banner style. Also, on the front panel, you’ll find an option for a door alarm. No, a sound doesn’t emit when someone opens the fridge or freezer. It’s essentially a fail-safe feature that prevents you from using any of the controls on the display when the door is locked. It’s easy enough to set: Simply hold down the lock button for three seconds to activate or deactivate. Does it Really Make coffee? 
The standout feature in this refrigerator is the inclusion of a Keurig K-Cup brewing system on the door. The coffee maker shares the same space with the water/ice dispenser. To make more room for coffee cups the base tray easily slides out. The tray can also be completely removed for cleaning. 
More: This smart coffee maker can brew 3 different ways, and has a built-in scale 
In order to make coffee, place a Keurig pod in the K-Cup brewer and slide it into place. Select the amount of coffee you’d like to make: six ounces, eight ounces, or ten ounces. Press the brew button and watch the 3, 2, 1 screen countdown. The noise level for brewing coffee is about 70 decibels, which is equivalent to the sound of a vacuum. When the coffee is finished brewing, it does make a louder sound that could jolt you awake if you’re not a morning person. The coffee tastes just as you’d expect of Keurig brewers, however, the 6-ounce coffee was a bit stronger due to it being more concentrated. Here are our test results: Temperature (Farhenheit)

posts.title: Pound Gets A Bump From The Trump Trade | Investing.com
posts.text:
EUR: GE CPI 0.8% vs. 0.8% 
North America USD: U of Michigan 10:00 
The pound soared in early European trade today, hitting a high of 1.2673 before finally succumbing to some profit taking by mid-morning London dealing. The move was partly driven by EUR/GBP flows which hit a multi-month low of 8566 before rebounding above the 8600 level. But the underlying strength in cable had more to do with the Trump trade than anything else. 
Ever since Donald Trump's surprising win on Tuesday, cable has shown relative strength, holding up well against the buck while euro lost four big figures since Tuesday's highs. The flow into cable can be attributed to the stall of progress on Brexit as the case weaves its way through UK courts as well as the election of Mr. Trump. 
One of the seminal threats against the UK economy as a result of Brexit was the promise by President Obama not to negotiate a bi-lateral trade deal. That policy will change completely under President Trump. Not only that, but Mr. Trump is very likely to force the EU to negotiate with UK on PM May's terms or threaten a cooling of trade ties between EU and US. In short, having Mr. Trump as President may have ameliorated some of the worst economic aspects of Brexit and the market is reacting to this development by relentlessly bidding cable. 
The pair now approaching strong resistance levels at 1.2700 and may run into some profit taking in the near term, but the dynamics in the trade have changed and it has now become a strictly 'buy the dip' affair with 1.2500 now becoming strong support and 1.3000 the key long term target of the bulls. posts.author: Larry Rulison
posts.title: GE worker settles harassment lawsuit
posts.text:
GE worker settles harassment lawsuit By Larry Rulison Published 8:57 am, Friday, November 11, 2016 Image 1 of / 1 Close Image 1 of 1 General Electric Co.'s Global Research Center in Niskayuna. A former female employee settled with the company over a workplace harassment suit she filed back in March. Terms of the settement were kept private. Source: Times Union archive less General Electric Co.'s Global Research Center in Niskayuna. A former female employee settled with the company over a workplace harassment suit she filed back in March. Terms of the settement were kept private. ... more GE worker settles harassment lawsuit 1 / 1 Back to Gallery 
NISKAYUNA — A former machine shop worker at General Electric's Global Research Center in Niskayuna who sued the company claiming she was subjected to a hostile work environment by male workers quietly settled with the company last month. 
It is unclear what the terms of the settlement are between GE and the former employee, Tami Knapp of Colonie. Knapp and her attorney had mediation talks with GE's attorneys back on Sept. 23 and reached an agreement after nearly eight hours of talks, according to federal court records. A judge overseeing the case signed off on the settlement on Oct. 19. 
Knapp sued GE back in March claiming that after she was hired as an inventory control specialist at the research center in 2013, she was under frequent attacks of intimidation by male workers. She also claimed that male workers in the machine shop area where she worked would openly watch pornography and tape lewd photos of women on equipment. 
She also claimed in her suit that female researchers located in other parts of the research center campus were afraid of stepping foot into the machine shop area where parts were made for research tests of potentially new GE devices and inventions. 
GE always vehemently denied Knapp's accusations and said it did not tolerate sexual harassment in the workplace. 
"We have zero tolerance for harassment and discrimination of any kind," GE spokesman Todd Alhart told the Times Union at the time. "This is a matter that we thoroughly investigated and found the claims could not be substantiated." 
Ira Lobel of Albany was the mediator in the settlement talks. Giovanna D'Orazio , Knapp's attorney, could not immediately be reached for comment. Today's Deals

posts.title: Exclusive: FedEx grounds one plane over GE engine part concern | Business | Reuters
posts.text:
[ - ] Text [ + ] 
By Jeffrey Dastin 
(Reuters) - FedEx Corp is grounding one of its planes temporarily that has an engine General Electric Co flagged after a passenger jet erupted in flames last month, a spokesman for the cargo airline told Reuters on Monday. 
Engine-maker GE on Friday alerted airlines about a small number of parts under investigation following American Airlines Flight 383, which caught fire on Oct. 28. The parts were made from the same lot of alloy as a turbine disk used by American, which GE subsequently discovered had a "material anomaly." 
While U.S. investigators have yet to assign blame for the non-fatal incident, they have found what appeared to be fatigue cracking where the disk had an anomaly. Experts have said the disk's corrupted material may indicate a manufacturing defect, either by the parts or metal maker. 
In a statement, FedEx spokesman Chris Allen said the company was notified that an engine in one MD11 aircraft was affected. 
"The aircraft associated with the affected engine is temporarily not in service until the engine is replaced. Safety is our top priority," he said. 
GE on Friday said all but one of the parts related to the anomalous disk were out of service. The component on the now-grounded FedEx plane had been the one in operation, GE spokesman Rick Kennedy said on Monday. 
"The part has been taken out of service, not because it was viewed as defective but because it was simply from the same lot of material," Kennedy said in a statement. 
The American Airlines flight from Chicago to Miami aborted takeoff following an "uncontained" engine failure, a rare event in which components spew from an engine and can tear through an aircraft cabin or rupture fuel tanks in the wings. The airline was flying a Boeing Co 767 aircraft with CF6-80C2 engines made by GE. Continued...

Military veterans employed by GE, GHS, Michelin and the Greenville Drive are hosting the first annual SC Veterans Upstate Salute at Fluor Field at 5 p.m. today.
This free event will include a Tracy Lawrence concert, 21-gun salute, fireworks and opportunities for veterans to learn about services that can help.
There will also be performances by Upstate high school JROTC groups, food and a helicopter take off following the National Anthem.
Parking is available at Greenville County Square and a shuttle will drive you over to the field from 3:30 until 8:30. Parking for people with disabilities is available at the field but spaces are limited.
There is no cost to attend, but registration is required at upstatesalute.com.
“This event was strategically done in the evening so children could come. The most important thing we can do is educate the next generation of veterans, and veteran supporters,” said Kevin McBride with GHS.

thread.title: From GE to Apple, Fresh Pledges for Diversity in Trump Era
thread.title_full: From GE to Apple, Fresh Pledges for Diversity in Trump Era

posts.author: Laura Putre
posts.title: From GE to Apple, Fresh Pledges for Diversity in Trump Era
posts.text:
NIMS Announces $500,000 in Apprenticeship Grants, Support ‘Areas of Angst’ 
Starting about midnight on Tuesday, Karyn Twaronite, global diversity and inclusiveness officer at consulting and accounting firm EY, said she received hundreds of emails from employees “raising concerns, thoughts and observations” as well as “areas of angst.” 
“I’m actually hopeful, because there’s so much dialog. We’ve been able to have conversations about subjects people never talked about before, like racism and sexism,” Twaronite said, adding that about two-thirds of EY’s employees are Millennials. 
There’s still cause for concern. Advocates of diversity see major changes in workplace regulations if Trump follows through with his pledge to rescind Barack Obama’s executive orders, which could include the ones below. And it’s still legal in 28 states to fire workers because they are gay. Amendments to Equal Employment Opportunity Executive Orders 11478 substituting “sexual orientation, gender identity” for “sexual orientation” and to 11246, substituting “sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, or national origin” for “sex, or national origin” Aug. 18, 2014 Establishing a coordinated government-wide initiative to promote diversity and inclusion in the federal workforce. 2011 Creating the White House Council on Women and Girls: Includes assisting women-owned businesses to compete internationally and working to increase participation of women in the science, engineering and technology workforce. 2009 
Trump will appoint his own attorney general and can name a new general counsel and chairman for the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, as well as change the leadership of the Department of Labor and National Labor Relations Board. The NLRB exerts broad influence over workplace issues, and the Department of Justice wrote key guidelines this year requiring the government to treat sexual orientation and gender identity as protected under the Civil Rights Act. 
During Obama’s two terms, the Justice Department and EEOC have taken the lead on discrimination cases involving religion, gender identity, sexual orientation and race--including high-profile diversity lawsuits against McDonald’s Corp., Abercrombie & Fitch Co. and AutoZone Inc. Aggressive Enforcement 
“The biggest effect will be in the agencies--the NLRB, DOL and EEOC--that have all been very aggressive in enforcing the laws,” said Cliff Palefsky, a civil-rights lawyer at McGuinn Hillsman & Palefsky in San Francisco. “I suspect we’re going to go back eight years, to when those agencies actually worked to undermine the laws. That’s unfortunate.” 
Matt Maloney, head of food-delivery company GrubHub Inc., generated controversy after the election with an email to employees decrying “the nationalist, anti-immigrant and hateful politics of Donald Trump” and said workers who don’t support a culture of inclusiveness should “reply to this email with your resignation because you have no place here.” In a statement posted Thursday on the company’s website, he clarified that GrubHub welcomes people of all political affiliations and the initial message was not meant as an attack on Trump voters. Move Past Rancor 
Many CEOs sidestepped specific comments on Trump and instead asked workers to try to move past the partisan rancor of the campaign. Starbucks Corp.’s Howard Schultz, who endorsed Clinton, told employees in a letter that “we have a choice in how we treat one another,” regardless of which candidate they supported. 
Companies increasingly recognize the need for employees to reflect their customers, and recruiting more women, minorities and people of different sexual orientations can help them stay competitive and innovative. 
“It’s a business imperative,” said George Nichols, senior vice president of government affairs at New York Life Insurance Co. “Businesses that don’t invest in diversity efforts will increasingly be at a competitive disadvantage, regardless of the political landscape.” 
The company held a town-hall meeting Thursday at which CEO Ted Mathas reiterated its commitment to a diverse workforce, Nichols said. 
Timothy Ryan, U.S. chairman at PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, encouraged employees to talk about their feelings the day after the election. “We’re doubling down” on diversity, he said in an interview. Some 44 percent of the new partners PwC named this year were women or minorities, while 47 percent of its workforce is female and 33 percent are minorities, he added. More Innovation 
“We and other companies understand the importance of diversity and inclusiveness to get more innovation, better answers to problems and to reach more customers -- and that’s not going to change,” he said. 
Trump’s candidacy inflamed racial tensions as he demonized Mexicans as rapists and Muslims as terrorists while also expressing support for police practices such as “stop and frisk,” which some consider a form of racial profiling disproportionately targeting blacks and Hispanics. Trump also was criticized on gender grounds, particularly following the release of a recording in which he makes vulgar comments about groping women. 
Corporate boards have been unforgiving with some top officials who engaged in arguably less crude behavior that could paint the company in a bad light or put it at legal risk. 
While the tone from the campaign was “disturbing,” it may not stop the progress toward a more diverse workforce, said Natasha Lamb, director for equity research and shareholder engagement at Boston-based Arjuna Capital, who filed nine diversity-related shareholder resolutions at technology companies this year. 
“Investors are part of a greater groundswell that is emboldening corporations to plot a more diverse and successful future,” she said. Following the election, “our work on gender equity is more important now than ever.”

thread.title: General Electric Company (GE) Stock Is an Overpriced Juggernaut
thread.title_full: General Electric Company (GE) Stock Is an Overpriced Juggernaut

posts.author: Lawrence Meyers
posts.title: General Electric Company (GE) Stock Is an Overpriced Juggernaut
posts.text:
General Electric Company (GE) Stock Is an Overpriced Juggernaut GE stock remains a landmark company, but it's way too expensive By Lawrence Meyers , InvestorPlace Contributor | Nov 11, 2016, 12:22 pm EST View All Posts 
General Electric Company (NYSE: GE ) is certainly a company that everyone has heard of, has a global brand name and remains a central part of American history. But does that mean you should buy, sell, hold or short GE stock? Let’s take a look. Source: Anthony Quintano via Flickr 
There are many pros to owning GE stock. I think one of the biggest advantages is the sheer size and diversification of the company. It isn’t just selling light bulbs anymore! In fact, GE is operating in areas that surprised even me, and the depth to which it is entrenched in much of the world’s infrastructure is staggering. 
The Power division generates power across all types of energy, from gas to nuclear. This division delivers about 20% margins and has a staggering $77 billion in backlog. GE also has a presence in renewable energy, with wind turbines, solar plants, geothermal plants and biomass power plants. Margins here are at about 7%, with $12 billion in backlog. Last year was huge for GE as it purchased Alstom, a massive $10 billion player in thermal and renewable energy. 
There’s still more energy in GE, and it is oil and gas, with drilling and production systems, floating platforms, reactors and all the gear that comes along with this stuff. Margins are solid here, at about 12% with $23 billion in backlog. 
Its energy management division has only 3.6% margins. Margins are 7.7% in the appliances and lighting division, the most famous of its products. Not too many people know that it has a healthcare division, as well, mostly in imaging — MRIs, CT scans and the like. That division carries 16% margins and a $17 billion backlog. The 7 Best Dividend Stocks to Buy for 2017 
Over in Aviation, it’s all about engines, and corresponding systems and services. Aviation is a high margin business with 22% yields and a whopping $151 billion backlog. Transportation focuses on railroad, marine, mining, stationary power and drilling industries. Somebody has to make those locomotives! Again, we have a high margin division (22%) with $22 billion in backlog. 
Finally, we have the capital division, which provides financial services to aviation, energy, and industrial businesses. GE is exiting the capital business by selling everything to its Synchrony Financial (NYSE: SYF ) spinoff.

thread.title: GE: Is The Baker Hughes Merger A Magic Trick?
thread.title_full: GE: Is The Baker Hughes Merger A Magic Trick?

posts.title: GE: Is The Baker Hughes Merger A Magic Trick?
posts.text:
GE's merger with BHI is nothing short of a magic trick. 
It adds ignites for Oil & Gas, adds scale and improves margins. 
This type of value-added dealmaking harkens back to the days of Jack Welch. 
The slowing global economy will continue to stymie GE's Industrial segment though. Sell GE. 
Click to enlarge 
GE CEO Jeffrey Immelt 
In a deal that shocked the financial markets General Electric (NYSE: GE ) announced it was merging its oil & gas operations with Baker Hughes (NYSE: BHI ). The transaction left me speechless for both its brazenness and creativity, and harkens back to the days of former CEO Jack Welch. 
Source: GE Oil & Gas Overview: Supplemental Transaction Information, November 7, 2016 GE is contributing its oil & gas operations; Baker Hughes is contributing its company. GE will own 62.5% of Newco and Baker Hughes 37.5%. GE will transfer $7.4 billion of cash to the venture that Baker Hughes will use to fund a $17.50 special dividend to its shareholders. The transaction assumed the contributed value of BHI at $23.4 billion, GE at $28.5 billion and the present value of cost synergies at $13.7 billion. Newco is projected to have a combined value of $51.9 billion. BHI's 37.5% stake would be valued at $24.6 billion. Including the $7.4 billion dividend, BHI would receive value of $32 billion or a 37% premium to its market capitalization prior to the deal. 
The transaction was a masterstroke for the following reasons: 
It Adds Growth 
GE built its Oil & Gas operations by investing $14 billion in over 30 acquisitions. Several deals were perfected when oil prices were over $100. Now that oil prices have free fallen the Oil & Gas segment has been a laggard. Revenue from the unit fell 18% Y/Y in Q3, underperforming the company's core Industrial revenue which fell 7%. That followed a 22% decline in the previous quarter. 
Based upon the company's portfolio of businesses, that decline would likely worsen sans Baker Hughes. 
Oil & Gas revenue peaked in 2014 when oil prices were above $100. Year-to-date Q3 2016 segment revenue of $9.5 billion was down 21% Y/Y. While short cycle businesses like land drilling were punished from the second half of 2014 to the first half of 2016, they rebounded in Q3 2016. Animal spirits returned to the North America oil patch and firms like Baker Hughes, Halliburton (NYSE: HAL ) and Weatherford (NYSE: WFT ) saw an uptick in revenue. 
That said, GE's Surface Technology business was the worst-performer year-to-date. But is poised to benefit from the rebound in land-drilling. A major revenue source for the TurboMachinery segment is aftermarket sales; however, drillers are still using spare parts from unused rigs in order to save money. Despite the rebound in land drilling, services revenue remains in the doldrums; this will likely hurt Digital Solutions going forward. Lastly, experts predict offshore and deepwater will be the last segments of the oil & gas industry to rebound. I expect Subsea to be one of GE's worst performers over the next 18 to 24 months. 
Nearly 30% of Baker Hughes' revenue is in North America -- the one segment experiencing a rebound. By merging with Baker Hughes, Oil & Gas can also benefit from that rebound. 
It Adds Scale 
In my opinion, Oil & Gas doesn't really have an identity. Subsea is one of the top providers of subsea equipment; however, the other segments seem like a hodge podge of businesses. Jack Welch was big on being number one or number two in each of GE's business segments. The Baker Hughes merger would make Newco the number two oil services company in the world, second only to Schlumberger (NYSE: SLB ). 
Click to enlarge Source: GE Presentation - Baker Hughes, A GE Company, October 31, 2016 
Newco would be in the top three of several product categories and have a major footprint in others. This is important; scale and market positioning would potentially make Newco the "go to" company for several products. It could also provide Newco the necessary leverage to drive terms and pricing with clients. 
It Increases Margins 
The Q3 2016 segment profit margin for Oil & Gas of 9% was down from the 10% achieved in Q2 and the 12% achieved in the year earlier period. Declining revenue and declining margins make Oil & Gas an albatross around GE's neck; the profit margin for GE's total Industrial segment was 12% in Q3. The merger with Baker Hughes is not only expected to add scale, but generate cost synergies. Such synergies could bring margins for Oil & Gas up to par with other Industrial businesses. 
In the second half of 2017 Newco is projected to have revenue of $14 billion and an EBITDA margin of 8%. Including $1.2 billion in expected cost synergies , margins are expected to improve to 23% in 2020 on $34 billion in revenue. Such margins which potentially rival the 23% margins Schlumberger achieved in Q3 2016. It would also potentially dig Oil & Gas out of its fog of declining revenue and declining profit margins. 
Conclusion 
The Baker Hughes merger ignites growth, increases scale and profit margins for Oil & Gas -- nothing short of a magic trick. That said, I remain bearish on GE; I believe a slow down in the global economy and future rate hikes will hurt the Industrial segment. Sell GE. Disclosure: I am/we are short HAL, SLB, WFT. I wrote this article myself, and it expresses my own opinions. I am not receiving compensation for it. I have no business relationship with any company whose stock is mentioned in this article. thread.title: Engine explosion on Boeing 767 poses puzzle
thread.title_full: Engine explosion on Boeing 767 poses puzzle

posts.author: The Seattle Times
posts.title: Engine explosion on Boeing 767 poses puzzle
posts.text:
Engine explosion on Boeing 767 poses puzzle GE, safety agencies work to find, correct problem Video Photo Soot covers the fuselage of an American Airlines jet that blew a tire, sparking a fire and prompting the pilot to abort takeoff before passengers were evacuated from the plane via emergency chute, at O’Hare International Airport in Chicago, Illinois, U.S.October 28, 2016. REUTERS/Jim Young The Seattle Times Nov 11, 2016 at 6:00 pm | Print View 
The nearly catastrophic explosion of an engine that caused a fire on an American Airlines Boeing 767 just short of takeoff in Chicago on Oct. 28 occurred when a specific part that had never before failed broke into pieces. 
The breakup of a heavy metal disk that rotates in the engine core reveals a new risk to airline passengers that, however rare, has already spurred a scramble by engine-maker General Electric and government safety agencies to find and fix the vulnerability. 
“The risk will be eliminated,” said John Goglia, a former National Transportation Safety Board member with more than 40 years’ experience in the aviation-safety industry. “Will it be eliminated before the next one? That’s the real question. Everything relies upon the timeliness of the system to correct itself.” 
American Airlines Flight 383 to Miami was speeding down the runway at O’Hare International Airport in Chicago when the second-stage disk of the high-pressure turbine broke apart inside the right engine with a loud explosion that blew metal shrapnel out through the engine casing. 
Hot metal ripped through the wing, igniting aviation fuel. Slamming on the brakes as the jet reached a speed of 154 miles per hour, the pilot brought the plane to a halt within 25 seconds and 900 yards further down the runway. 
Moving quickly, the cabin staff evacuated all 161 passengers and nine crew using the escape slides on the undamaged left side of the aircraft. Twenty people suffered minor injuries. 
GE spokesman Rick Kennedy stresses the reliability of the CF6 engine involved. The latest models, introduced in the 1980s, currently power about 4,000 widebody jets, including Boeing 767s, 747s and Airbus A330s, and have flown for more than 220 million hours. 
“The CF6 is the workhorse engine of jumbo jets on a level never experienced before,” Kennedy said. 
The NTSB said one piece of the broken disk went through the right wing, then arced high over the airplane and came crashing through the roof of a UPS warehouse almost 1,000 yards away. 
“Any time a turbine disk fails, it’s a big deal,” said Goglia. Your next Nation & World articles

thread.title: From GE to Apple, fresh pledges for diversity in Trump era
thread.title_full: From GE to Apple, fresh pledges for diversity in Trump era

posts.title: From GE to Apple, fresh pledges for diversity in Trump era
posts.text:
From GE to Apple, fresh pledges for diversity in Trump era By Richard Clough,Jeff Green and Laura Colby, Bloomberg Published: November 12, 2016 9:35 AM CDT Updated: November 12, 2016 11:05 AM CDT 0 shares facebook twitter email comments × 
Chief executive officers at some of the largest U.S. companies, from General Electric to Apple, are reassuring employees they support workplace diversity as a salve to anxieties caused by the bruising presidential election. 
Jeffrey Immelt affirmed GE's commitment to "people of all races, genders and sexual orientations" in an internal blog post Wednesday musing on the election. That echoed Apple CEO Tim Cook's message to workers that the tech giant welcomes everyone, "regardless of what they look like, where they come from, how they worship or who they love." Oscar Munoz of United Continental Holdings said in a message to employees that they represent "every creed and conviction, background and belief." 
Diversity issues have come to the fore as the presidential campaign exposed and deepened bitter divisions on matters such as the treatment of women and minorities; the rights of lesbian, gay, bi-sexual and transgender workers; and gender disparities on the job. Following Donald Trump's surprise victory over Hillary Clinton this week, companies now are grappling with how to ease tensions and move forward. 
Thousands of people in cities including Boston, Chicago, Seattle and New York have marched, shut down highways and burned effigies of Trump to protest the electoral shift to the right. 
'Areas of Angst' 
Starting about midnight on Tuesday, Karyn Twaronite, global diversity and inclusiveness officer at consulting and accounting firm EY, said she received hundreds of emails from employees "raising concerns, thoughts and observations" as well as "areas of angst." 
"I'm actually hopeful, because there's so much dialog. We've been able to have conversations about subjects people never talked about before, like racism and sexism," Twaronite said, adding that about two-thirds of EY's employees are millennials. 
There's still cause for concern. Advocates of diversity see major changes in workplace regulations if Trump follows through with his pledge to rescind Barack Obama's executive orders, which could include the ones in the table below. And it's still legal in 28 states to fire workers because they are gay. DATEEXECUTIVE ORDERJuly 21, 2014Amendments to Equal Employment Opportunity Executive Orders 11478 substituting "sexual orientation, gender identity" for "sexual orientation" and to 11246, substituting "sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, or national origin" for "sex, or national origin"Aug. 18, 2011Establishing a coordinated government-wide initiative to promote diversity and inclusion in the federal workforceMar. 11, 2009Creating the White House Council on Women and Girls: Includes assisting women-owned businesses to compete internationally and working to increase participation of women in the science, engineering and technology workforce
Trump will appoint his own attorney general and can name a new general counsel and chairman for the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, as well as change the leadership of the Department of Labor and National Labor Relations Board. The NLRB exerts broad influence over workplace issues, and the Department of Justice wrote key guidelines this year requiring the government to treat sexual orientation and gender identity as protected under the Civil Rights Act. 
During Obama's two terms, the Justice Department and EEOC have taken the lead on discrimination cases involving religion, gender identity, sexual orientation and race -- including high-profile diversity lawsuits against McDonald's Corp., Abercrombie & Fitch Co. and AutoZone Inc. 
Aggressive Enforcement 
"The biggest effect will be in the agencies -- the NLRB, DOL and EEOC -- that have all been very aggressive in enforcing the laws," said Cliff Palefsky, a civil-rights lawyer at McGuinn Hillsman & Palefsky in San Francisco. "I suspect we're going to go back eight years, to when those agencies actually worked to undermine the laws. That's unfortunate." 
Matt Maloney, head of food-delivery company GrubHub Inc., generated controversy after the election with an email to employees decrying "the nationalist, anti-immigrant and hateful politics of Donald Trump" and said workers who don't support a culture of inclusiveness should "reply to this email with your resignation because you have no place here." In a statement posted Thursday on the company's website, he clarified that GrubHub welcomes people of all political affiliations and the initial message was not meant as an attack on Trump voters. 
Move Past Rancor 
Many CEOs sidestepped specific comments on Trump and instead asked workers to try to move past the partisan rancor of the campaign. Starbucks Corp.'s Howard Schultz, who endorsed Clinton, told employees in a letter that "we have a choice in how we treat one another," regardless of which candidate they supported. 
Companies increasingly recognize the need for employees to reflect their customers, and recruiting more women, minorities and people of different sexual orientations can help them stay competitive and innovative. 
"It's a business imperative," said George Nichols, senior vice president of government affairs at New York Life Insurance Co. "Businesses that don't invest in diversity efforts will increasingly be at a competitive disadvantage, regardless of the political landscape." 
The company held a town-hall meeting Thursday at which CEO Ted Mathas reiterated its commitment to a diverse workforce, Nichols said. 
Timothy Ryan, U.S. chairman at PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, encouraged employees to talk about their feelings the day after the election. "We're doubling down" on diversity, he said in an interview. Some 44 percent of the new partners PwC named this year were women or minorities, while 47 percent of its workforce is female and 33 percent are minorities, he added. 
More Innovation 
"We and other companies understand the importance of diversity and inclusiveness to get more innovation, better answers to problems and to reach more customers -- and that's not going to change," he said. 
Trump's candidacy inflamed racial tensions as he demonized Mexicans as rapists and Muslims as terrorists while also expressing support for police practices such as "stop and frisk," which some consider a form of racial profiling disproportionately targeting blacks and Hispanics. Trump also was criticized on gender grounds, particularly following the release of a recording in which he makes vulgar comments about groping women. 
Corporate boards have been unforgiving with some top officials who engaged in arguably less crude behavior that could paint the company in a bad light or put it at legal risk. 
Read more: Sex, the C-Suite and Trump 
While the tone from the campaign was "disturbing," it may not stop the progress toward a more diverse workforce, said Natasha Lamb, director for equity research and shareholder engagement at Boston-based Arjuna Capital, who filed nine diversity-related shareholder resolutions at technology companies this year. 
"Investors are part of a greater groundswell that is emboldening corporations to plot a more diverse and successful future," she said. Following the election, "our work on gender equity is more important now than ever." 
(Updates with GrubHub comment in 11th paragraph.) 
--With assistance from Carol Hymowitz To contact the reporters on this story: Richard Clough in New York at rclough9@bloomberg.net, Jeff Green in Southfield, Michigan at jgreen16@bloomberg.net, Laura Colby in New York at lcolby@bloomberg.net.
